title: Sleepwalker ordered to tell people he spends night with about his 'sexsomnia'
text:
A man cleared of molesting a woman because he was sleepwalking is ordered to tell people about his "sexsomnia" when he spends the night away from home.

Dale Kelly claimed he was experiencing an episode of the rare disorder, which causes involuntary sexual behaviour during sleep, when he climbed into his friend's bed and touched his girlfriend intimately.

The 21-year-old apprentice electrician previously told York Crown Court he was dreaming and thought she was a woman he was dating.

He wept in the dock after a jury found him not guilty by reason of insanity of sexual assault by penetration following a week-long trial in August.

Judge Simon Hickey today sentenced Kelly, making him subject to a five-year sexual harm prevention order which bans him from contacting the woman.

The order also means that if he ever sleeps away from home he must inform everyone in the house of his "affliction" so they can take any necessary steps to "protect themselves".

He was additionally handed a two-year supervision order which involves him completing an alcohol awareness course and "adapted thinking skills programme".

Judge Hickey said that Kelly's disorder means he poses a threat not only to the girl he was cleared of molesting, but women in general.
